ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: About how cyber security is tightly intertwined with foreign policy. Developing the norms of cyberspace. Brief overview of how ai and machine learning will integrate into society
I developed a good understanding of all areas of cybersecurity and AI as they relate to national security.
I learned a lot about the intricacies of cyberspace on the policy side - its a lot of soft skill knowledge, you wont really get into the technical parts of it.

I learned a lot about the state of cybersecurity policy, particularly with regards to national security. We read a lot of thought-provoking pieces and I think it's a very accessible introduction to both technical and policy aspects of cybersecurity for someone who only has experience with one of those.

How to think about the intersection of cybersecurity / cyber policy and national security. We also had the chance to meet different policymakers and hear about their perspectives on US cyber policy, which added an applied component to the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very reasonable course load and good variation of assignments

Strengths: Ted is the best! Also, he really cares about the students and their understanding which is so clear in how he always makes himself available and invites students to events with guests outside of the classroom.
This is one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. The seminar setting & mix of undergrad/grad students was incredible. In no other class was I ever so intimidated by my peers (in a good way).

Prof Wittenstein has tons of connections so he really makes the class an interactive experience. We frequently had very high profile guest speakers and would be invited to dinners and outside events that were being put on by ISS. I wish I had received more feedback on my papers though.

Strengths: a lot of hands-on learning and events, Ted knows what he's doing 
Weaknesses: I wish there had been more structured debate in class in which two sides could've debated an issue more thoroughly

The Yale Cyber Leadership Forum is highly additive to the class; a great way to hear from experts across the policy and technical worlds. The guest speakers in class were also high-ranking elected officials or retired policymakers who all brought a lot of first-hand expertise and insights to our topics of discussion. The case studies and readings were sometimes very focused on the technical aspects of different cyber attacks, but overall it was a great class to learn about cyber policy.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Prof. Wittenstein is great and makes everyone feel welcomed/able to contribute
Yes, of course. It's incredibly difficult to get in, but if you can it's quite rewarding.
Yes - whether youre interested in security or cyberspace or not, this class is such a great experience
Yes absolutely if you have any interest in any sector of those topic!

Yes, if you're looking to focus mostly on the policy aspect of cyber. The class is not going to focus as much on technical concepts beyond understanding the "need-to-know" for a policy discussion, so you have to be interested in the politics and policy considerations around cybersecurity and cyber warfare. Professor Wittenstein is very knowledgeable, has a really cool background, and the guest speakers are very cool as well.
